    static int
    getVarIntSize​(int varInt)
    Calculates the number of bytes required to fit the supplied int (0-5) if it were to be read/written using readVarInt() or writeVarInt(int).
    Proudly stolen (incl. description) from the Minecraft PacketBuffer.

    • writeVarInt

      public io.netty.buffer.ByteBuf writeVarInt​(int value)
      Writes a compressed int to the buffer. The smallest number of bytes to fit the passed int will be written. Of each such byte only 7 bits will be used to describe the actual value since its most significant bit dictates whether the next byte is part of that same int. Micro-optimization for int values that are expected to have values below 128.
      Proudly stolen (incl. description) from the Minecraft PacketBuffer.
      Parameters:
      value - Integer that should be written compressed.
      Returns:
      The underlying ByteBuf with the written, compressed int, specified in value.

    • readVarInt

      public int readVarInt()
      Reads a compressed int from the buffer. To do so it maximally reads 5 byte-sized chunks whose most significant bit dictates whether another byte should be read.
      Proudly stolen (incl. description) from the Minecraft PacketBuffer.
      Returns:
      the compressed int read from the underlying ByteBuf.
      Throws:
      RuntimeException - if the var int is too big.

    • getVarIntSize

      public static int getVarIntSize​(int varInt)
      Calculates the number of bytes required to fit the supplied int (0-5) if it were to be read/written using readVarInt() or writeVarInt(int).
      Proudly stolen (incl. description) from the Minecraft PacketBuffer.
      Parameters:
      varInt - int from which the size should be computed
      Returns:
      the number of bytes required to fit in varInt.
      See Also:
      readVarInt(), writeVarInt(int)

    • writeString

      public PacketBuffer writeString​(String value)
      Writes a string. This string could be read with writeCharSequence(CharSequence, Charset) (unconfirmed) or readString(int). Also, the second variant does not require an exact length of the string but a max length which is pretty easier for the transfer of Strings.
      Parameters:
      value - The String should be written.
      Returns:
      this for builder.
      See Also:
      writeCharSequence(CharSequence, Charset), readString(int)

    • readString

      @UnstableApi @Deprecated(forRemoval=false) public String readString​(int maxLength)
      Deprecated.
      Use readString() instead, as the maxLength is almost useless and was only used in Minecraft for such things as a scoreboard.
      Reads a String that is maximum maxLength characters long.
      Parameters:
      maxLength - Maximum length as Integer of the string to read.
      Returns:
      The string that was read.
      Throws:
      io.netty.handler.codec.DecoderException - if
      • the received encoded string is longer than maximum allowed.
      • The received encoded string length is negative. This would be very weird.
      • The received string length is longer than specified in maxLength
      See Also:
      readString(), readCharSequence(int, Charset), readCharSequence()

      Deprecated.

      Writes an AudioFormat.Encoding to the underlying ByteBuf via the name it contains.
      Parameters:
      encoding - value
      Returns:
      this

    • readEncoding

      public AudioFormat.Encoding readEncoding()
      Reads an AudioFormat.Encoding from the underlying ByteBuf.
      Returns:
      the read ByteBuf
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the read string matches no encoding.
